message.content:
We need to “close‐the books” for the cost that is “recorded” on the income statement. In our example (see the provided sample) the cost item comes from the sale entries – each sale row has a “cost_amount” associated that represents (roughly) what it “cost” the company to produce or procure the item that was sold. (In our sample data the “Total Cost” was obtained by summing the cost_amount figures on all sale transactions.) 

Let’s do the work step‐by‐step for the new problem:

1. Identify the rows having type = “Sale”. (Only sale transactions will carry a “cost_amount” value that appears in the “cost_amount” column.)  
2. Read each sale row’s “cost_amount” (the 24th column).

The sale transactions we have are:

• Sale20240106004  
  – cost_amount = 500000.0

• Sale20240108006  
  – cost_amount = 1500000.0

• Sale20240111008  
  – cost_amount = 800000.0

• Sale20240114010  
  – cost_amount = 500000.0

• Sale20240119016  
  – cost_amount = 1000000.0

• Sale20240122019  
  – cost_amount = 500000.0

• Sale20240123021  
  – cost_amount = 800000.0

• Sale20240124022  
  – cost_amount = 500000.0

• Sale20240125024  
  – cost_amount = 1500000.0

• Sale20240126025  
  – cost_amount = 500000.0

• Sale20240131033  
  – cost_amount = 500000.0

• Sale20240202035  
  – cost_amount = 500000.0

• Sale20240204038  
  – cost_amount = 1500000.0

3. Now add these numbers sequentially:
  • 500000.0  
  • + 1500000.0 = 2000000.0  
  • + 800000.0 = 2800000.0  
  • + 500000.0 = 3300000.0  
  • + 1000000.0 = 4300000.0  
  • + 500000.0 = 4800000.0  
  • + 800000.0 = 5600000.0  
  • + 500000.0 = 6100000.0  
  • + 1500000.0 = 7600000.0  
  • + 500000.0 = 8100000.0  
  • + 500000.0 = 8600000.0  
  • + 500000.0 = 9100000.0  
  • + 1500000.0 = 10600000.0

Thus the final total cost is 10600000.00.

We therefore output the result in the required json format.

Final answer:

{
  "solution": {"Total Cost": "10600000.00"}
}
